content: Is anyone working or wants to work in the near future about the fact that ℤ[√-2] is a euclidean domain? I am thinking about giving this problem to some students. It would be nice if at the end they could PR this to mathlib, but this is not going to happen soon.
Ahah, I wanted to formalize my Groups, Rings and Modules example sheet in Lean, and this is one of the questions. But don't expect I actually will.
I don't want to block anybody if the result is needed for something else of course. But if it is just one random theorem to prove I would like to "book" it :D
I had a student prove Z[omega] is a Euclidean domain and another student prove Z[sqrt(3)] is a Euclidean domain :-)
there's some not very long finite list of these quadratic Euclidean domains right?
In some sense yes, in another sense this is a profound unsolved problem

If you want the norm to be the norm coming from Galois theory, then yes. But if you are happy to be flexible with the norm then it's an unsolved problem having something to do with the Riemann Hypothesis.
For ℤ[√-D] (I mean the ring of integers, so there can be a denominator) we know the list for positive D (it is D = 1, 2, 3, 7, 11), but in general it is complicated.
ED.pdf Here are some notes I wrote on the question in 2009

Wikipedia says "the generalized Riemann hypothesis implies that a ring of real quadratic integers that is a principal ideal domain is also a Euclidean domain", but I think we don't even know if there are infinitely many real quadratic fields whose ring of integers is a PID.
But this is for the "loose" definition of ED. If you stick to the norm coming from Galois theory then -11<=D<=73 are the bounds.
Ah yes, I just read it. Unbelievable that the proof that ℤ[√14] is euclidean is so recent!
It's a question in analytic number theory, perhaps surprisingly.

My favourite proof in there is the proof that the integers of Q(sqrt(-19)) is not a Euclidean domain (but it is a PID); it's surprisingly short (and works for 43,67,163 as well). This shows that you need infinitely many units for this PID<->ED thing to be possibly true. But the moment you have units, arguments such as the Q(sqrt(-19)) one break down.
